Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: Night court remains one of the funniest series I have ever seen.  The characters are unusual, and they show how the law was changing in the 1980s.  Judge Harry Stone is interesting because he has an interest in justice, not just the letter of the law.  Dan Fielding is hilarious, and he really does make a person wonder if there is a real Dan Fielding out there somewhere.This is a funny, funny, heart-warming show.
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: Unlike most other shows, Night Court didn't lose much of a beat after 6 seasons, and its irreverent (and sometimes politically incorrect) humor is as enjoyable today as it was 20-plus years ago. Our favorite episodes are "The Clip Show" featuring Richard Sanders (from WKRP) as a city auditor threatening to throw the book at Harry, and "From Snoop To Nuts" in which Christine thinks she saw Harry accept a bribe from a mobster. I would much rather see this show than 90% of the sitcoms that are airing today.
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: I'm SO GLAD they FINALLY came out with season 6. Night Court is a GREAT show, VERY funny.  The show itself is definitely worth 5 stars (or more). However, I rated this particular DVD 4 stars as there are NO subtitles (shame on Warner Bros.), and the clarity of a couple of the episodes is rather dark.
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: I'm very disppointed that Night Court Season 4, 5, 6,... don't have closed caption (CC) or Subtitled for Deaf and Hard of Hearing (SDHH). How come Night Court Season 1, 2 and 3 have it? Remember that Law 504 that require ALL DVD to have CC or SDHH.
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: By Season 6, the innovative, funny Night Court started to show signs of aging. After hitting the ratings peak of # 7 in seasons 3 and 4, the show slipped in Season 5 to # 21, and then season 6 finished a disappointing # 29. It was still one of the better sitcoms on TV at the time, but some of the routines were getting a little long in the tooth.Season 6 begins where Season 5 leaves off. Dan has left to fulfill his obligation to the US Army Reserves when the gang gets word that his plane crashed in Alaska and Dan is presumed dead. Season 6, Episode 1 shows that Dan survived and is forced to operate on an Eskimo woman after he accidentally breaks the doctors' hands. By Episode 2 he is on his way back home and arrives in time for his own funeral.In later episodes, Dan runs for State Assembly, Harry dates a porn star, Bull is smitten (again?), Mac is chased by an old girlfriend, Roz is jailed after delivering toys to kids at Christmas that belonged to a Scrooge-like character, and Christine volunteers to take care of a friend's baby with hilarious results.Night Court was one of my favorite shows from the 1980s along with Remington Steele and Cheers (whatever became of NBC?), and the entire series thus far on DVD has been good. But be aware that at this point, their best seasons were behind them.
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: As Night Court begins its 1988-89 Season, Assistant District Attorney Dan Fielding (John Larroquette) is listed as missing and presumed dead when his plane crashes in the Arctic Ocean.Judge Harry Stone (Harry Anderson) cautions the others against expecting Dan to still be alive after 2 weeks of futile search-and-rescue efforts, but Legal Aid Attorney Christine Sullivan (Markie Post) refuses to give up hope and prays for Dan's safe return. Dan, meanwhile, is alive on a remote island, saved by a seal. And that's just the start of the season.Subsequent side-splitting episodes see Bull Shannon(Richard Moll) glue his fingers to the side of his head, Mac Robinson(Charles Robinson) deal with a classmate who has more on her mind than studying, and Harry jailing Roz (Marsha Warfield) when she won't divulge the location of a truckload of toys mistakenly given to needy kids.Justice prevails in this 3-Disc, 22-Episode Collection.This 1988-1989 Season takes me back to memory lane to when I was 16 years old in my Sophomore year in high school when I used to watch it every Thursday night after THE COSBY SHOW and when NBC's motto was "Come Home to The Best".
summary: From the producers of Barney Miller
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season

reviewText: I had bought seasons 4 and 5 on this MOD title and was... less than impressed.The price was higher than previous seasons, and a burn on a consumer-grade off-the-shelf disc* was a turnoff.  For the price commanded, a low-grade disc is a ripoff.Especially as season 4's release had a mastering error with the audio losing sync in one episode, which is not attributable to the master videotapes shot circa 1985 or whenever...Night Court's final solid season would be its seventh, and season 6 was a letdown from season 5.  After season 7 the show would never really recover.* those purple-dye discs that have nothing near the claimed lifespan of the professionally pressed (silver, reflective metallic-looking) media; in the past when I archived on burnable DVDs, I had problems within a couple of years. Fleecing is for sheep.  Not for people.
Title: Night Court: The Complete Sixth Season
